DataElement.preferredName: Ductal Breast Carcinoma In Situ Histologic Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Text term for a ductal carcinoma in situ histologic specification.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Ductal Breast Carcinoma In Situ Histology Classification
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information related to the systematic arrangement of the cells and constitute tissues of Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS), a carcinoma entirely confined to the mammary ducts, by classes or groups.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) is a carcinoma entirely confined to the mammary ducts.  There is no evidence of invasion of the basement membrane.  Currently, DCIS is classified into three categories: High-grade DCIS, intermediate-grade DCIS and low-grade DCIS. In this classification the DCIS grade is defined by a combination of nuclear grade, architectural growth pattern and presence of necrosis.  The size of the lesion as well as the grade and the clearance margins play a major role in dictating the most appropriate therapy for DCIS. --2002

Concepts.definition: A breast carcinoma entirely confined to the mammary ducts. It is also known as DCIS. There is no evidence of invasion of the basement membrane. Currently, it is classified into three categories: High-grade DCIS, intermediate-grade DCIS and low-grade DCIS. In this classification the DCIS grade is defined by a combination of nuclear grade, architectural growth pattern and presence of necrosis. The size of the lesion as well as the grade and the clearance margins play a major role in dictating the most appropriate therapy for DCIS.

Property.preferredDefinition: The study of the structure of the cells and their arrangement to constitute tissues and, finally, the association among these to form organs.  In pathology, the microscopic process of identifying normal and abnormal morphologic characteristics in tissues, by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains.:Classification; the grouping of things into classes or categories.

Concepts.definition: The study of the structure of the cells and their arrangement to constitute tissues and, finally, the association among these to form organs.  In pathology, the microscopic process of identifying normal and abnormal morphologic characteristics in tissues, by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains.
A method of generalization, the systematic arrangement of entities into classes or groups based on mutual similarity and certain differing characteristics.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

DataElementConcept.changeDescription: Update to use OC DCIS with concept name dw 05-13-2015

ValueDomain.preferredName: Ductal Breast Carcinoma in Situ Histologic Type
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A carcinoma entirely confined to the mammary ducts.  It is also known as DCIS.  There is no evidence of invasion of the basement membrane.  Currently, it is classified into three categories: High-grade DCIS, intermediate-grade DCIS and low-grade DCIS. In this classification the DCIS grade is defined by a combination of nuclear grade, architectural growth pattern and presence of necrosis.  The size of the lesion as well as the grade and the clearance margins play a major role in dictating the most appropriate therapy for DCIS._Refers to the type of tissue in which a tumor originated.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A morphologic finding indicating the presence of an architectural pattern dominated by the presence of small papillary structures.

Concepts.definition: A morphologic finding indicating the presence of a growth pattern dominated by the presence of small papillary structures.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A ductal carcinoma in situ of the breast in which the tumor cells fill the ductal spaces as solid sheets.

Concepts.longName: Breast Ductal Carcinoma In Situ, Solid Type
Concepts.definition: Breast ductal carcinoma in situ in which the tumor cells fill the ductal spaces as solid sheets.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Comedo; having a black or dark core or plug.

Concepts.definition: Having a black or dark core or plug.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Cribriform; having the appearance of a sieve: containing many perforations.

Concepts.definition: Having the appearance of a sieve: containing many perforations.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: of or relating to or resembling papilla.

Concepts.definition: Of or relating to or resembling papilla.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Concepts.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An intraductal breast carcinoma characterized by a papillary growth within a large cystic duct. There is no evidence of invasion of the breast parenchyma.

Concepts.definition: An intraductal breast carcinoma characterized by a papillary growth within a large cystic duct. There is no evidence of invasion of the breast parenchyma.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A glandular secreting cell in which the apical portion of the secreting cell is cast off along with the secretory products that have accumulated therein.

Concepts.definition: A glandular secreting cell in which the apical portion of the secreting cell is cast off along with the secretory products that have accumulated therein.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: An object needed to perform a diagnostic, therapeutic or research activity.
